subject: Technology
title: E-Waste: Where Old Phones Go
description: Learn E-Waste: Where Old Phones Go in one minute.

hook.text: The world discards over 5 billion phones per year. Most end up in landfills or worse.

buildup.text: Phones contain gold, copper, and rare earth minerals. They also contain lead, mercury, and arsenic.

discovery.text: Much of the world's e-waste is shipped to developing countries where workers dismantle it by hand.

twist.text: Recycling phones is expensive and complex. It's often cheaper to mine new materials from the Earth.

climax.text: The upgrade cycle accelerates the problem. A phone lasts years but most people replace theirs in two.

punchline.text: Your old phone is someone else's toxic waste problem.

quiz.question: Why is phone recycling difficult?
options: Phones don't contain any valuable materials
It is expensive and often cheaper to mine new materials
